item.title: Why we are age?
item.dc:creator: k3nny1550
item.description:
Mass Effect postulated that human life expectancy could be increased to around 200, but I remember hearing somewhere that the human brain can’t live past 120 or so. So even if people somehow figured out full cyberization a la Ghost in the Shell, their brain could still only live 120 years.

item.title: Why we are age?
item.dc:creator: geekofalltrades
item.description:
I actually have no idea what this sort of thing would do concerning cancers and the like. The basic idea is, though, that bacteria are immortal (barring fatal mutations). This is because their chromosomes are closed circles, meaning that the entire chromosome can be replicated by DNA polymerase with no loss of information. Eukaryotes (the vast majority of multicellular organisms) have linear chromosomes; a straight piece of DNA open on each end. Theoretically if you could make the linear chromosomes circular you could greatly extend human life expectancy. Of course, it’s way more complicated than that; circularizing human chromosomes would have all sorts of weird consequences that I couldn’t even begin to imagine.

Read full topic

item.title: Why we are age?

item.description:
So basically its probably possible to live forever, but you would die anyways? (I read somewhere that if someone did this, the body would produce more than nessesary cells, and it would develop into cancer)

Read full topic

item.title: Why we are age?
item.dc:creator: geekofalltrades
item.description:
I’m sure they have, but I’m a bioinformatician, so it’s not really my department. I’m not even certain that it’s possible; the issue is that over time, telomere sequences net so many mutations that the action of telomerase either isn’t enough to compensate or is prevented altogether. The best way to prevent aging would be to circularize human chromosomes, but the technical and scientific challenges in such an endeavour are frankly staggering.

Read full topic

item.title: Why we are age?
item.dc:creator: k3nny1550
item.description:
geekofalltrades:

Aging is commonly thought to be a result of telomere degredation. Telomeres are a consequence of linear chromosomes: because DNA Polymerase is only able to replicate DNA in a 5’ to 3’ direction, there are portions at the end of a linear chromosome that remain unreplicated after each cell cycle. Telomerase riboproteins then come in to fill the gap with a highly specific repetitive sequence. In this way, the chromosome doesn’t get shorter and shorter after each cell cycle. Over time, however, the telomere is degraded beyond the capacity of telomerase’s catabolic action, and the chromosome begins losing functionality, leading to cell death. Unfortunately, the nature of DNA means that this trait is inherited in all daughter cells through the process of mitosis, so once telomeres begin to degrade, it’s only a matter of time before integral cell systems fail and the collective - the human being - dies.

Has the scientific community been working on methods to synthesize Telomerase riboprotines in such a manner as to slow or even stop this process, thereby preserving cellular regeneration at a constant rate?

Read full topic
